contents.context:
President Moon Jae-in says South Korea will be creating a new "smart fund" to invest in new industries that can turn the country into a digital powerhouse in the post-pandemic era.
He unveiled the idea Thursday in a meeting with the founders of local startups listed on the Forbes Under 30 Asia which features young innovators and entrepreneurs across the region.
It was Moon's first on-site schedule in what is now his fourth year in office.


The government will be aggressively pushing for a Korean version of the New Deal to take the lead in industries in the non-face-to-face digital sector. I will soon let the people know of the government's plans to foster digital infrastructure and non-contact industries and to digitalize social overhead capital.

While pointing out the difficulties faced by startups Moon also announced another financial package worth 1.8 billion U.S. dollars.
He also vowed all out efforts to grow local startups into global unicorns that is, private companies valued at over one billion dollars.

The support package will seek out potential startups to provide them with funding and guarantees and to help them discover markets. The government will help innovative ideas become commercialized and will put them on the global stage.

The president said innovation to create new jobs and breathe life into the economy is no longer just an option but is a must.
He called for continued efforts from young entrepreneurs, to turn the crisis into an opportunity.
Kim Min-ji, Arirang News.
Reporter : kimmj@arirang.com
contents.headline:
President Moon unveils plan to create 'digital smart fund' to invest in new industries
Updated: 2020-05-14 17:14:38 KST

contents.context:
As of noon Friday, 133 COVID-19 cases linked to Itaewon clubs have been confirmed and the government believes this number could rise further.
Many of those cases are secondary infections.
For example, 14 cases reported were linked to a private academy instructor in Incheon, who was confirmed last Saturday.
The instructor had been teaching classes without wearing a face mask.
The majority of those 14 are either middle or high school students, and some were infected from being in contact with other students.
The instructor had hidden their employment details, which led to a delay in government's reaction.
It is still aggressively responding to the cluster.

"15,000 have been tested yesterday alone, and 35,000 tests have been done so far in regards to the Itaewon clubs."

The government has promised anonymity for those being tested, and it will also look into credit card information and CCTV footage to thoroughly check for anyone with possible contact with those infected.
But it is still appealing for anyone who visited the clubs to come forward voluntarily.

"Please note not being tested could expose not only yourself but people around you and our society, so please be responsible."

The government also said that this coming weekend is a critical moment for the country's social distancing efforts.
And the related agencies will have to review whether additional measures have to be put in place to respond to the rise in cases.
South Korea has seen a total of 10,991 confirmed cases as of midnight Thursday with a new reported death, bringing the death toll to 260.
Kim Do-yeon, Arirang News
Reporter : tkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
133 cases linked to Itaewon clubs so far including more students
Updated: 2020-05-14 17:14:32 KST

contents.context:
May is the month of showing gratitude with flowers
Drive-thru flower markets help local flower farms
-Vehicles enter this way please.
-Please come this way.
Every May, we hold the 'Goyang International Flower Exhibition'.
But this year, because of COVID-19, we were unable to.
So to help with flower purchasing and to keep the flower farms safe,
we've designed this drive-thru flower market.
I wish all families happiness throughout Family Month in May.
Purchasing fresh, local flowers at cheaper prices
Early sell-outs of 16 different kinds of plants,
including carnations, herbs, and succulents
With it being Family Month in May, there are many occasions for us buy flowers.
It would be nice if we could buy flowers anywhere in the country with this drive-thru method.
I hope for COVID-19 to end all around the world as soon as possible.
Hope for flower farming, love for family and loved ones
Reporter : cinejenna910@naver.com
contents.headline:
VJ Drive Thru Flower Market
Updated: 2020-05-14 17:14:09 KST

contents.context:
As the country struggles to trace the thousands linked to the Itaewon cluster infection, health authorities will make use of the advanced technologies available.
Seoul's health ministry says bars and clubs could use QR code technology that contains visitors' information provided by cell phone carriers.
The data won't be open for the businesses to read. But in case of an emergency, the government can collect the information from telecom companies.
Bluetooth system can also be used to trace contacts within a certain area.
Reporter : kelee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea plans to adopt ICT technology to track nightclubs visitors
Updated: 2020-05-14 17:13:56 KST

contents.context:
The education ministry said Thursday that it is not considering any further postponement of the opening of schools for students in their third and final year of high school.
They will start on May 20th, as currently scheduled, despite the recent surge in new cases.

"Ahead of the reopening of schools, the top priority for the ministry is students' safety as we work to make an effective education curriculum."

The education ministry is asking high school seniors to test themselves for COVID-19 at home. Those with a temperature higher than 37.5 degrees Celsius or with other suspected symptoms are not allowed to go to school.
Students are losing precious time to get ready for the college entrance exam coming up at the end of the year.
The ministry said, however, that the test's difficulty level will not be adjusted and will be similar to previous years.
The test was originally set for November 19th, but has been postponed for 2 weeks until December 3rd.
Meanwhile, Minister of Education Yoo Eun-hae is recommending that parents not send their children to private educational insitutes, known in Korea as hakwons.
The virus was spread recently to students at multiple hakwons by a teacher who caught it visiting clubs in Itaewon.
If hakwons do hold classes, then she urged local governments to carry out stricter quarantine inspections on them.

"We strongly advise all private educational institutes to comply with the quarantine measures and stick with online classes if they choose to hold classes."

Hakwons had been looking forward to the new, relaxed system of "distancing in daily life," but now they'll have to practice full-scale social distancing.
Eum Ji-young Arirang News.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea's schools to start reopening as planned on May 20
Updated: 2020-05-14 17:13:52 KST

contents.context:
South Korea reported 29 new cases of COVID-19 on Thursday, …many linked to clubs and bars in Seoul's popular multicultural neighborhood of Itaewon.
This marks the seventh straight day of double-digit increases in new infections.
Twenty-six cases were community transmissions and three were imported.
Total infections in South Korea now stand at ten,nine-hundred-91.
The country reported one new COVID-19 death, …bringing the death toll to two-hundred-60.
More than 20-thousand people are being tested.
Reporter :
contents.headline:
S. Korea reports 29 new COVID-19 cases Thursday after clubber-triggered infections
Updated: 2020-05-14 13:13:39 KST

contents.context:
Chinese President Xi Jinping told President Moon Jae-in during phone talks late Wednesday that he remains committed to visiting South Korea this year.
The two leaders talked for over 30 minutes at the request of President Xi.
President Moon said the Chinese leader's visit to Seoul is more important than anything else for their bilateral relations.
They agreed to begin negotiations when the COVID-19 situation eases and the conditions are right.
It was their second phone conservation since the outbreak with their previous one happening in February.

Moon and Xi also shared their response to COVID-19 highlighting their close cooperation.
They welcomed a new "fast track" entry system for business people between the two sides.
The fast track system which simplifies entry procedures has been in effect since May 1st.
Thanks to the deal, some 200 people from South Korean companies were able to enter China and begin work on Wednesday.
Xi said he's looking forward to strengthened cooperation and communication with South Korea, while Moon expressed hope the fast track system becomes a model for the global community.

Regarding the Korean Peninsula, President Xi stressed his continued support for the peace process to which President Moon expressed his appreciation.
The top office did not elaborate further.
Kim Min-ji, Arirang News.
Reporter : kimmj@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Xi reaffirms commitment to visit S. Korea this year during phone talks with Moon
Updated: 2020-05-14 07:08:33 KST

contents.context:
Eight people, most of them students, have been confirmed of COVID-19 after coming into contact with an instructor working at a private academy in Incheon who had contracted the virus at a nightclub in Itaewon, Seoul.
Incheon City said Wednesday that five high-schoolers, one middle-school student, a parent and a colleague have tested positive.
Those students were either attending the same private academy as the infected instructor, or were being tutored by the instructor.
The instructor had reportedly lied about their workplace during an earlier investigation.

"Incheon City is going to sue the infected patient number 102 based on the contagious disease prevention act as the patient lied during the investigation about their job, where they had been, and that they taught students."

Currently, over one-thousand people are being tested in relation to the case,as they had attended the same churches in Incheon as two of the eight people.

As of midday Wednesday, the total number of infections related to the nightclubs in Itaewon had reached 119.
Seventy-six of them were infected at the clubs, while the rest were secondary infections.
Seoul had the most cases, followed by Gyeonggi-do Province.
But the cluster infection has spread out to other regions too, including Busan and Jeju.
South Korea reported 26 new COVID-19 cases on Wednesday, most of which were related to the cluster infection in Itaewon.
The total number of infections in the country now stands at 10,962.
Yoon Jung-min, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Students in Incheon confirmed to have COVID-19 after contact with instructor infected in Itaewon
Updated: 2020-05-13 17:20:41 KST

contents.context:
Seoul resident Hwang Hyeok takes the subway every day, but ever since the start of the COVID-19 outbreak, he has been worried about people not wearing masks.

"I take the subway every day and when I see people who are not wearing masks, it makes me worried and frustrated."

But starting from Wednesday, people must wear masks on crowded subway trains in the capital.
This comes as Seoul Metropolitan Government has expanded its "distancing in daily life" measures to include the use of public transport.

"We are trying our best to keep the subway environment safe such as by disinfecting trains more than 4 times a day. So as long as citizens follow this new measure of wearing masks, I believe it will be safe to take the subway."

When carriages are classed as "congested", people will be asked to put on masks, and further boarding will be restricted.
This level of congestion is when carriages reach over 150 percent of their recommended quota, based on the weight of 160 people in a carriage.
Sensors in the carriages can detect this weight and show current congestion levels.

For those who have forgotten to bring a mask from home, stations have placed vending machines that sell masks at street price.

"I totally support the change. I feel more relieved that people now have to wear masks on the subway. I also carry around extra masks just in case I forget to bring one."

Seoul Metro is also planning to provide passengers with daily congestion forecasts for the following day on its website and social media like Twitter at 6 PM.
For the busiest lines including lines 2, 4 and 6, extra trains will run during rush hour.
Kim Sung-min, Arirang News
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Seoul city makes it compulsory to wear masks on crowded trains
Updated: 2020-05-13 17:20:12 KST

contents.context:
On what's supposed to be her first day back at school, high school senior Byeon Sung-eun is heading to a shared study room.
The start of school has been postponed once again, from May 13th to the 20th.
To Byeon, that one week delay impacts a major life event the college entrance exam.

"By now, I should have had already taken a mock version of the test, and based on that, I'd be preparing strategically for the actual exam. But that's not happening right now."

And because of the delay, a hectic semester awaits.
At least 5 major exams are planned, and midterms are set to take place just two weeks after students get back to the classroom.

"Of course that's not enough time to prepare. But what's more concerning is that most online classes are provided by EBS, the educational broadcast channel, but the actual tests will be made by our teachers at school. That means the material will be different."

Also, summer break will be shortened, leaving students with less time to spend in college applications.

All students can do at this point is take their classes online and study by themselves while waiting for school to get back to normal.

"Some students are also attending private academies.
Here in Seoul's Daechi-dong, where many academies are concentrated,…teachers and students are busy trying to fill the gap caused by the lack of school."

"Seniors have less time to prepare for the college entrance exam because they have to catch up with their school classes. That puts them at a disadvantage, physically and psychologically, compared to graduates who are re-taking the exam."

There's growing speculation that the college entrance exam will be rescheduled again, but the education ministry says that won't happen as long as schools open this month.
Lee Kyung-eun, Arirang News.
Reporter : kelee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
School delay means high school seniors lose time to prepare for college exam
Updated: 2020-05-13 17:20:05 KST

contents.context:
South Korea aims to locate all visitors to the Itaewon nightclubs and bars affected by the recent cluster infections within this weekin order for them to be tested for COVID-19.
Speaking at a government meeting on Wednesday, Prime Minister Chung Sye-kyun said there are still some people who could not be reachedbut it's just a matter of time before they are tracked down.
He has urged for those people to get tested willingly and added that no personal information will be recordedto prevent any issues of privacy.
Should they test positive for COVID-19, only their recent travel history will be checked so to prevent any secondhand transmissions.
Among those whose cell phones had connected to base stations in the close vicinity of the clubs between April 24th and May 6th, 11-percent were foreign nationals.
In response, Seoul has pledged to distribute details of the new COVID-19 measures in 12 different languages and will ask the relevant embassies to encourage their citizens to get tested.
Seoul Mayor Park Won-soon said the number of people getting tested daily in Seoul is 8 times larger due to the Itaewon community transmission.
But, has expressed concern over young people in their twenties and thirties who have a wide travel range and may have visited enclosed spaceswhere the virus can be easily transmitted.
Meanwhile, three other nightclubs in Itaewon have been confirmed to have cases of COVID-19.
Mayor Park warned that if things get worse, stricter measures to ensure that entertainment facilities are following quarantine guidelines could be implemented.
Hong Yoo, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoohong@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Gov't targets tracing all visitors to Itaewon clubs this week for virus tests: PM
Updated: 2020-05-13 17:19:54 KST
